sense.name: Make changes in order to remove abuse or injustice; improve by correcting errors.
sense.examples: Diplomatic efforts struggled to reform the political system. Both candidates seek to reform the country's health system.

sense.name: Lead to abandon a wrong course of life in favor of a better one; change for the better.
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[agent[human]] REFORM NP2[patient[human]] NP1[patient[human]] REFORM
sense.examples: The Church reformed me. The employee was instructed to reform his conduct. The lazy student promised to reform.

sense.name: Produce by cracking or breaking up the molecules of.
sense.examples: The plant reforms gas. Manufacturers are out to reform oil as quickly as possible.
